+ 522.
James Boyde
, of London, soldier , was indicted, for that
he being an evil disposed person, and not having any regard to the laws of the land, after the first day of June 1733. to wit, on the eleventh of July last , at the parish of St. Bride's
, with a certain loaded gun, which the said
James Boyde
, then and there had, and held in both his hands; did unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously, fire off at the person of
Thomas Palmer
, with an intent to kill him .

Thomas Palmer
. On the seventh of July last, one
Mary Shirley
, wife of
Lewis Shirley
, came to my house, and desired to lie there; I told her I had no bed , unless she would accept of my servant maid's, and she lay there Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday; and there was a report that a man had hurried Mrs. Shirley into a coach, and ordered the coachman to drive to the French Change; I took company with me, and went to Monmouth Street, which they call the French Change. I went in and saw the prisoner at the bar with Mrs. Shirley, and she said pray do not let this man be with me, for he is going to strip me of all I have; and another man that came in and I, held the prisoner, till the woman got away from him, and I did not go home for two hours afterwards; and my boy told me there was a soldier came to my shop, and enquired for me, for I went to the tavern, and staid two hours with some gentlemen; and my boy said, lord, master, here has been the man that came with the gun, and he says , come in when you will, he will blow your brains out: I went to see whether he was behind my shop (I live in Fleet Market) I saw a soldier (the prisoner) sitting at a bench behind Mr. Cowell's shop; I went up to the prisoner, and said, do you want me; he said yes G - d D - mn your blood to blow your brains out ; and he took hold of the gun, and I heard the gun clink a little, and I fell down, and several people thought I had been murdered.
Q. Was the prisoner's face black?
Palmer. I cannot say that it was, my lord; I go in fear and danger of my life upon account of this fellow.

The Prisoner was acquitted upon this indictment, and the court ordered him to find security for his good behaviour to the prosecutor for a twelve month; himself to be bound in the penalty of 100 l. and two securities in 50 l. each, and to remain in prison till he has found sureties .
